titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the New York City Department of Traffic
Parking Lot Photographs and Related Publications
1949-1988
PR 451
titlestmt.author: Joseph Ditta (November-December 2022)

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-25 10:03:01 -0400.

did.unittitle: New York City Department of Traffic parking lot photographs and related publications
did.abstract: Photographs of sites of projected and existing municipal parking lots and garages operated by the New York City Department of Traffic throughout the five boroughs. Some views show street parking conditions, towing and auto body shops, traffic congestion, and pedestrian safety posters. A number of photographs capture areas of the city that have since become unrecognizable through early 21st-century gentrification and building projects. The collection includes approximately ninety supplementary publications such as feasibility studies, master plans, and neighborhood redevelopment proposals for some of the locations documented by the photographs.
did.physloc: This collection is stored offsite. For information on making arrangements to consult it, please go to www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
did.langmaterial: The documents in this collection are in English.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is stored offsite. For information on making arrangements to consult it, please go to www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized by format in two series:

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Formed to oversee tasks originally controlled by the New York Police Department, the New York City Department of Traffic, under its first commissioner, Thomas T. Wiley (1950–1961), instituted strict parking rules, changed some streets from two-way traffic to one, and installed the first parking meters (1951). To free the city's congested streets and to generate revenue in busy shopping and business districts, the department began building municipal parking lots and garages. The first garage appeared in Flushing, Queens, in 1954, followed in the 1960s and '70s by others in Jamaica, Queens, Downtown Brooklyn, East 153rd Street in the Bronx, and Eighth Avenue at West 53rd Street in Manhattan. Today, Manhattan alone boasts some 100,000 off-street parking spaces in about 1,600 facilities, some of them managed by the Department of Transportation, which succeeded the Department of Traffic in 1977.

[For further information, see Sigurd Grava, "Parking" and "Traffic" in The Encyclopedia of New York City, 2nd edition (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2010). The Green Book: Official Directory of New York City lists city-operated parking facilities for various years.]

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The collection should be cited as: New York City Department of Traffic Parking Lot Photographs and Related Publications, PR 451, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, New-York Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Archivist Joseph Ditta arranged and described this collection in November-December 2022.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The New York City Department of Traffic Parking Lot Photographs and Related Publications document the sites of projected and existing municipal parking lots and garages (some during construction) maintained by that agency throughout the five boroughs. Beyond these the collection's photographs (1958-1979) show street parking conditions and traffic congestion, and in some instances capture neighborhood scenes that have been so drastically changed by 21st century building projects as to be virtually unrecognizable today. The approximately ninety publications (1949-1988) supplementing the photographs—some of which were issued by the Department of Traffic, others by related city and state agencies—include feasibility studies, master plans, and redevelopment proposals for areas like Fulton Arcade (Brooklyn), Little Italy (Manhattan), and Jamaica Center (Queens).

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of sites of projected and existing municipal parking lots and garages—some during construction and after completion—administered by the New York City Department of Traffic, as well as views of street parking conditions, towing and auto body shops, traffic congestion, and pedestrian safety posters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized in six subseries. Files within each subseries are listed alphabetically. Titles in [brackets] were devised by the archivist.

defitem.label: Subseries I.A.
defitem.item: Photographs: New York City-wide and elsewhere, 1965-1971

did.unittitle: Subseries I.A. Photographs: New York City-wide and elsewhere

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interior views of an unidentified parking garage, with closeups of car fenders and bumpers. The date on the original folder may not apply to when the photographs were taken.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The date on the original folder may not apply to when this single photograph was taken. The 1966 New York City transit strike occurred in January.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Parking Field Sites 39 St. & 2 Ave." Contains views of unidentified parking lots and structures around New York City. Images of identifiable locations have been removed and filed under their respective boroughs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Duplicate Pictures of Proposed Garages." Contains no photographs, only a handwritten list of "Pictures in Files," some of which were sent "for photography" on December 9, 1971.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of Traffic Department Safety Education Program posters with such slogans as "Look Before You Cross . . . at the Corners, Of Course" and "Mickey Mantle Says -- Play it Safe! Cross at Corners, Not mid block." Includes an image of traffic / transit officials posed with a cartoon drawing of an anthropomorphized computer on which are the words "The Best Thing That's Happened To Parking Tickets Since Disappearing Ink." One image published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Views of taxis on
(1) Park Avenue and East 59th Street (June 12, 1968)
(2) Seventh Avenue between West 30th and 31st Streets (June 18, 1968)
(3) Avenue of the Americas and Central Park South (June 27, 1968)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Views of auto body and towing companies in
(1) Bronx (Mott Haven; 4151 Park Avenue; 291 West 230th Street)
(2) Brooklyn (1302 60th Street)
(3) Manhattan (3816 Ninth Avenue; 766 Elevnth Avenue)
(4) Queens (100th Avenue & 217th Street; 56th Street & Northern Boulevard; Jamaica?)
(5) uncertain locations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Contents of two folders labeled "Traffic Congestion" and "Traffic Congestion N.Y.C. 1965"; views of
(1) Fifth Avenue at 54th and 57th Streets (undated)
(2) Madison Avenue between East 50th and 51st Streets (undated)
(3) Park Avenue at East 29th (May 19, 1970), East 49th (May 27, 1965), and East 50th Streets (May 27, 1965)
(4) West 37th Street and Broadway (May 27, 1965)
(5) Queens Plaza[?] (undated)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Contents of two folders labeled "Underground Garage" and "Underground Garage's [sic] (other cities)"; views of
(1) Boston
(2) Chicago
(3) Detroit
(4) New York City, Brooklyn (Civic Center; unidentified)
(5) New York City, Manhattan (Madison Square Park)
(6) San Francisco

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Original folder labeled "Meters—Vandalized." Contains views of vandalized meters in
(1) Brooklyn (Albee Square Field, Grant Avenue Field)
(2) Manhattan (Leonard Street Field, between Lafayette & Centre Streets)
(3) Queens (Astoria, Flushing, Steinway)
(4) uncertain locations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Meters (Vandelized)" [sic].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of the Jerome Avenue - 170th Street Field, located south of West 170th Street between Inwood and Jerome Avenues, Bronx.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

(1) "Westchester Square, Bronx, Preliminary Feasibility Analysis" (March 13, 1972).
(2) "Westchester Square, Bronx, Proposed Site for Parking Deck with Retail" [photocopied map] (May 14, 1975).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of Westchester - Zerega Field, Westchester Avenue between Zerega Avenue and Herschall Street, Bronx. Published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of a site near the Cross-Bronx and Sheridan Expressways.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of Albee Square Field, Flatbush Avenue between Fleet and Willoughby Streets, Brooklyn. The Abraham & Straus (A&S) and Martin's department stores on Fulton Street are visible in the background.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Atlantic & Court Garage Bklyn. Pictures." Contains construction views of the municipal garage at Atlantic Avenue and Court Street, Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Bay Ridge Pictures Maps" [sic; no maps present]. Contains construction views of the Bay Ridge Municpal Parking Garage, 8501 Fifth Avenue at 86th Street, Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of Bensonhurst No. 1 Field, 1763 86th Street, Brooklyn. Published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Brooklyn Queens Exp. Brooklyn Hights [sic]." Contains views of the split-level Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in Brooklyn Heights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of Brownsville Field, north of Pitkin Avenue between Amboy Street and Hopkinson Avenue (now Thomas S. Boyland Street), Brooklyn. Published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of the projected site of Canarsie Field at Rockaway Parkway and Farragut Road, Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of a parking field near Crescent and Fulton Streets, Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of East New York No. 1 Field on the north side of Atlantic Avenue between Van Sinderen Avenue and Havens Place. One published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Parking Field Flatbush #1." Contains one view of the northwest corner of Bedford and Snyder Avenues, showing Flatbush No. 1 Field (now occupied by P.S. 6) and the adjacent former Flatbush Town Hall at 35 Snyder Avenue, Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Perspective renderings (photocopies) of a "Combined Parking Area and Playground" at Avenue H between Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues, Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of Front - York Street Field, where Front and York Streets converge near the Brooklyn Bridge and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, currently the site of the luxury tower Olympia Dumbo, 30 Front Street.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Grant Ave Field for zoning variance." Contains views of Grant Avenue Field, 581 Grant Avenue, Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kings Highway No. 1 Field was located on the block bounded by Kings Highway, East 14th and 15th Streets, and Avenue P. The photographs in this folder show the south side of Avenue P between East 14th and 15th Streets, and the west side of East 14th Street looking south from Avenue P towards the entrance/exit to the field, which surrounded the firehouse at 1635 East 14th Street.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of Kings Highway No. 2 Field, located just south of Kings Highway between East 13th and 14th Streets. Published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1963 (see Box 3, Folder 5).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A perspective drawing (photocopy) of the Livingston - Bond Garage, on Livingston Street between Bond and Hoyt Streets, Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Park Avenue Field extended on Park Avenue beneath the elevated Brooklyn-Queens Expressway from Navy Street to Grand Avenue. This folder contains a view near the intersection of Park and Vanderbilt Avenues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of Williamsburg Field on the block bounded by Rutledge Street, Wythe Avenue, Heyward Street, Wallabout Street, and Kent Avenue, opposite Classon Triangle, Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of conditions at the intersection of Broadway and Grand Street, Manhattan, after elimination of two-way traffic. Published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1963 (see Box 3, Folder 5).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Delancey & Essex Sts. Pictures." Contains construction views of the Delancey and Essex Municipal Parking Garage, 105-113 Essex Street and 112-120 Ludlow Street, Manhattan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "14th St. Garage (Union Square) Manhattan (Pictures)." Contains views of the south side of East 14th Street between Third and Fourth Avenues, adjoining Lüchow's restaurant at 110 East 14th Street. With renderings of the municipal parking garage proposed for the site.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of the Eighth Avenue Municipal Garage, between West 53rd and 54th Streets, Manhattan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Kinney Garage (28th St. West of B'way, Man.)." Contains views of a parking garage on the north side of West 28th Street between Broadway and Sixth Avenue, Manhattan (approximately 25 West 28th Street).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "33rd & 8th Ave." Contains views of the vicinity of West 33rd Street and Eighth Avenue, Manhattan. Date determined from a typed description of the proposed parking facility (included) and by the presence of Pennsylvania Station in some of the photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Mid-block crossing at 34th St." Contains views of West 34th Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, Manhattan, with the crosswalk extending from 130 West 34th across to Macy's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of a municipal parking garage, 9 West 35th Street (north side), Manhattan.

did.unittitle: [West 77th Street between Central Park West & Columbus Avenue]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "77 St CPW." Contains views of the south side of West 77th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, Manhattan. A notation on the original folder indicates that the photographs dated January 22, 1971 were taken between 1:10 and 1:35 p.m.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Before and after construction views of Astoria Field on 29th Street between Astoria Boulevard and Hoyt Avenue South, Queens. Later view published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of Far Rockaway No. 1 Field, at Beach 22nd Street and Mott Avenue, Queens, under the elevated railroad trestle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of Far Rockaway No. 2 Field, at Beach 21st and 22nd Streets at Mott Avenue, Queens. Published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of Flushing No. 1 Field (and later parking deck), on the block bounded by 39th Avenue, Union Street, 37th Avenue, and 138th Street, at different stages. The photographs capture the lost Macedonia A.M.E. Church at 37-22 Union Street (demolished c. 2018-2019), which was surrounded by the parking lot.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Forest Hills Site, 71 Rd. Queens - Pictures." Contains views of 71st Road and vicinity, near the Forest Hills station on the Long Island Rail Road.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Hillside & Midland Parkway, Pictures." Contains views of a parking field at Hillside Avenue and Avon Street, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views possibly of Jamaica No. 1 Field, on Liberty Avenue between Union Hall Street and New York Boulevard (renamed Guy R. Brewer Boulevard in 1982), Queens. The site is now occupied by York College's Health and Physical Education Building.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of Jamaica No. 2 Field, on the block bounded by 90th and 91st Avenues, 168th and 169th Streets, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Jamaica." Contains views of the Jamaica Theatre (155-16 Jamaica Avenue) and vicinity, as well as Jamaica No. 4 Field, at 90th Avenue between Parsons Boulevard and 160th Street, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Jamaica #4 Photographs." Contains construction views of Jamaica No. 4 Field, at 90th Avenue between Parsons Boulevard and 160th Street, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Jamaica #5." Contains construction photographs of the municipal parking lot at 168th Street and 93rd Avenue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Garage—Jamaica #5 169th St. & Archer." Contains views of traffic/transit officials at the completed facility at 168th Street and 93rd Avenue, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Jamaica 6." Contains construction photographs of Jamaica No. 6 Garage, at Archer Avenue and 165th Street, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Jam Ave & 163 St Qns | 6/16/67 | Jam 7." Contains views of a parking field and proposed structure on the block bounded by 89th Avenue, 162nd Street, Jamaica Avenue, and 163rd Street, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Queens Plaza Garage. Pictures. TF 446." Contains views of the construction of the Queens Plaza Garage, located on Bridge Plaza South between 28th Street and Jackson Avenue, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Queens Plaza Garage. Pictures. TF 446." Contains views of the construction of the Queens Plaza Garage, located on Bridge Plaza South between 28th Street and Jackson Avenue, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Queens Village (Operation Main Street) Pictures." Contains views of Jamaica Avenue and 218th Street, site of the Queens Village Field, 218-02 Jamaica Avenue, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of Rego Park No. 1 Field between 57th and 59th Avenues, 92nd and 94th Streets, Queens. One published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A view of Rego Park No. 2 Field, between 92nd and 94th Streets, 59th Avenue, and the Long Island Expressway, Queens. One published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Roosevelt & Main." Contains views of the intersection of Roosevelt Avenue and Main Street, Queens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Original folder labeled "Rosedale - Pictures." Contains views of the site of the future Rosedale Field at the Rosedale Station of the Long Island Rail Road (Francis Lewis Boulevard between Sunrise Highway and North Conduit Boulevard):
(1) From L.I.R.R. at Francis Lewis Boulevard
(2) Looking east at Francis Lewis Boulevard
(3) Looking west at Francis Lewis Boulevard
(4) Looking east at Brookville Boulevard
(5) Looking west from Hook Creek Boulevard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder labeled "Van Wyck—Various Merges." Contains views of traffic near entrance and exit ramps on the Van Wyck Expressway, photographed September 11 and 15, 1969, and May 11, 1970.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of the proposed site of Great Kills Field, 3928 Amboy Road, near Hillside Terrace, Staten Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Views of the proposed sites of three municipal parking fields
(1) New Dorp No. 1 (New Dorp Lane between 4th Street and New Dorp Plaza)
(2) New Dorp No. 2 (New Dorp Lane at 9th Street)
(3) New Dorp No. 3 (along South Railroad Avenue?)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of Port Richmond No. 1 Field, at the intersection of Maple and Grove Avenues, Staten Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of traffic and parking conditions in the vicinity of Port Richmond Avenue, Post Avenue, and Heberton Avenue, Staten Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of St. George Field, at Hyatt Street, between Central Avenue and St. Mark's Place. One photograph shows the 1864 Brighton Heights Reformed Church (320 St. Mark's Place), which was destroyed by fire in 1996. One view published in the City of New York, Department of Traffic Annual Report, 1962 (see Box 3, Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of the proposed site of Stapleton No. 1 Field, between Prospect and Cross Streets, and Bay Street and railroad right-of-way, Staten Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Views of the proposed site of Stapleton No. 2 Field, Staten Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Approximately ninety publications, some issued by the Department of Traffic, others by related New York City and State agencies, supplementing the locations documented in the photographs of Series I.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized in six subseries. Files within each subseries are listed chronologically.

defitem.label: Subseries II.A.
defitem.item: Publications: New York City-wide and regional, 1949-1988

did.unittitle: Subseries II.A. Publications: New York City-wide and regional
